{{Infobox musical artist | name = 1788-L | background = temporary | image = | birth_name = | birth_date = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electronic music|Electronic]]|[[new beat]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|[[Record producer]]|[[Disc jockey|DJ]]|[[musician]]}} | instrument = [[Digital audio workstation]] | origin = | years_active = 2018–present | label = Deadbeats | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Illenium]]|[[Said The Sky]]|[[Rezz]]|4AM|Blanke}} | website = {{URL|1788-L.com}} }} '''1788-L''' is an [[electronic music]] producer.{{cite web|author=Meadow, Matthew|title=1788-L Is Already Getting Lots Of Hype After Only Three Tracks|work=YourEDM|url=http://www.youredm.com/2018/02/23/1788-l-already-getting-lots-hype-three-tracks/|accessdate=26 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops One Of The Most Insane Daft Punk Remixes We Have Ever Heard|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/02/1788-l-drops-one-insane-daft-punk-remixes-ever-heard/|accessdate=27 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=Dexter's Beat Laboratory Vol. 32|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/dexters-beat-laboratory-vol-32/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} They rose to fame in 2018 with a remix of [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]'s "Particle Arts" uploaded onto their [[SoundCloud]] account.{{cite web|title=Virtual Self- Particle Arts ( 1 7 8 8 – L / F L I P )|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/02/13/virtual-self-particle-arts-1788-l/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} Other releases following this include "Multiverse" (with 4AM) and a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler".{{cite web|author=Evanson, Austin|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=[[Dancing Astronaut]]|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} ==Career== On 26 January 2018, 1788-L uploaded their debut release, "Replica", on [[SoundCloud]].{{cite web|title=R E P L I C A by 1788-L|work=[[SoundCloud]]|url=https://soundcloud.com/1788-l/replica-22|accessdate=27 March 2018}} A [[music download|digital download]] release of they song was issued on 2 February 2018.{{cite web|author=1788-L|title=Replica - Single|work=[[iTunes Store]]|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/replica-single/1342467838|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 9 February 2018 they released a remix of "Particle Arts" by [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]. On 2 March 2018, a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler" (from ''[[Tron: Legacy (soundtrack)|Tron: Legacy]]'') was released, and premiered on [[Dancing Astronaut]].{{cite web|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 30 March 2018, a remix of "[[Radioactivity (song)|Radioactivity]]" by [[Kraftwerk]] was released.{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops Newest Track, A Remix Of Kraftwerk’s “Radioactivity”|work=YourEDM|url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-newest-track-a-remix-of-kraftwerks-radioactivity/|accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops A Fire Remix of a Kraftwerk Classic|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-a-fire-remix-of-a-kraftwerk-classic/|accessdate=3 April 2018}} His debut extended play, ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]'', which comprises four tracks was released on August 24, 2018 through [[Zeds Dead]]' label, Deadbeats. 1788-L performed their first live show on July 7, 2018 in [[Los Angeles, California]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |title=Half of Soundcloud Showed Up to 1788-L's Crazy Debut in LA Last Night |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=July 8, 2018 |website=Your EDM |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180708222226/https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |archive-date=July 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 25, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:7em;"| Title ! style="width:15em;"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]''{{Cite web |url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |title=1788-L’s destructive debut EP, ‘S E N T I E N C E,’ has finally arrived |last=Norris |first=Asher |date=24 August 2018 |website=[[Dancing Astronaut]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825021038/https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |archive-date=25 August 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018}} | * Released: 24 August 2018 * Label: Deadbeats * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:15em;"|Title ! style="width:2em;"|Year ! style="width:12em;"| Album |- !scope="row"| "Replica"{{cite web|title=1788-L on Spotify|work=[[Spotify]]|url=https://open.spotify.com/artist/7oB4pCSzvvRtZka6DxXUfN?si=Mm339cnFS6q0u_n2N3aAzA|accessdate=27 March 2018}} |rowspan="10"|2018 |rowspan="4" {{N/A|Non-album singles}} |- !scope="row"| "Pulsar Beam"{{cite web|title=New Music Time - 1788-L|work=New Music Time|url=https://newmusictime.com/Artist/6452616/1788-L|accessdate=27 March 2018}} |- !scope="row"| "Multiverse"{{cite web|title=1788-L Released Another Outstanding Tune With 4AM Called “Multiverse”|work=Thissongslaps|url=http://www.thissongslaps.com/2018/03/1788-l-released-another-outstanding-tune-with-4am-called-multiverse/|accessdate=27 March 2018}}
(with 4AM) |- !scope="row"| "Destiny"{{Cite web |url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/04/27/1788-l-and-blanke-combine-forces-to-create-their-own-destiny/ |title=1788-l and Blanke Combine Forces to Create Their Own Destiny |website=EDMSauce |access-date=4 May 2018}}
(with Blanke) |- ! scope="row" | "Sound of Where'd U Go"{{Cite web |url=https://edm.com/music-releases/illenium-sound-of-whered-u-go |title=Illenium Drops Massive New VIP Edit "Sound of Where'd U Go" |last=Rounsefell |first=Kierstin |date=March 11, 2018 |website=EDM.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512090200/https://edm.com/music-releases/illenium-sound-of-whered-u-go |archive-date=March 12, 2018 |dead-url=no |access-date=March 12, 2018}}
(with [[Illenium]], [[Kerli]], and [[Said the Sky]]) | ''Awake (Remixes)'' |- ! scope="row" | "Cyberspace"{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/06/15/1788-l-cyberspace/ |title=1788-l Releases New Cinematic Dystopian Masterpiece, “Cyberspace” |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=15 June 2018 |website=Your EDM |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616101818/https://www.youredm.com/2018/06/15/1788-l-cyberspace/ |archive-date=16 June 2018 |accessdate=16 June 2018}} | {{N/A|Non-album single}} |- !scope="row"| "[[Hex (Rezz and 1788-L song)|Hex]]"
(with [[Rezz]]){{Cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/8463479/rezz-1788-L-hex |title=Rezz & 1788-L Get Real Weird on 'Hex': Listen |last=Bein |first=Kat |date=29 June 2018 |website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180630142756/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/8463479/rezz-1788-L-hex |archive-date=30 June 2018 |accessdate=30 June 2018}} | ''[[Certain Kind of Magic]]'' |- !scope="row"| "Full Burst"{{Cite web |url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-l-teams-totto-lead-single-f-u-l-l-b-u-r-s-t-forthcoming-ep/ |title=1788-L teams up with totto on lead single from forthcoming EP, ‘F U L L / B U R S T ‘ |last=Oh |first=Lindsey |date=August 3, 2018 |website=[[Dancing Astronaut]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180804060135/https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-l-teams-totto-lead-single-f-u-l-l-b-u-r-s-t-forthcoming-ep/ |archive-date=August 4, 2018 |accessdate=August 4, 2018}}
(with Totto) | rowspan="2"| ''Sentience'' |- !scope="row"| "Nu Ver Ka"{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/08/17/1788-l-unleashes-experimental-n-u-v-e-r-k-a-off-debut-ep/ |title=1788-l Unleashes Experimental “N U / V E R / K A” Off Debut EP |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=August 17, 2018 |website=Your EDM |accessdate=August 18, 2018}} |- |- !scope="row"| "Abyss"{{Cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/a-b-y-s-s-single/1439611402|title=A B Y S S - Single by 1788-L & TYNAN on Apple Music |accessdate=October 31, 2018 |website=[[iTunes Store]]}}
(with Tynan) | {{N/A|Non-album single}} |- |} ===Remixes=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! rowspan="1" style="width:15em;"| Title ! rowspan="1"| Year ! colspan="1" style="width:12em;"| Original artist(s) |- !scope="row"| "Particle Arts"{{cite web|title=1788-L Just Flipped Virtual Self’s "Particle Arts" And It's Massive|work=Thissongslaps|url=http://www.thissongslaps.com/2018/02/1788-l-just-flipped-virtual-selfs-particle-arts-and-its-massive/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} | rowspan="5" | 2018 | [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]] |- !scope="row"| "Rinzler"{{cite web|title=Daft Punk's "Rinzler" Gets a Killer Bass Heavy Remix From 1788-L|work=Runthetrap|url=https://runthetrap.com/2018/03/03/daft-punks-rinzler-gets-killer-bass-heavy-remix-1788-l/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} | [[Daft Punk]] |- !scope="row"| "[[Radioactivity (song)|Radioactivity]]"{{cite web|title=1788-L Releases A Monster Remix of Kraftwerk's Radioactivity|work=Runthetrap|url=https://runthetrap.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-releases-monster-remix-kraftwerks-radioactive/|accessdate=3 April 2018}} | [[Kraftwerk]] |- !scope="row"| "[[Would You Ever]]"{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/06/01/1788-l-skrillex-would-you-ever/ |title=Mystery Producer 1788-L Drops Blistering New Remix of Skrillex's "Would You Ever" |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=1 June 2018 |website=Your EDM |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180602062602/https://www.youredm.com/2018/06/01/1788-l-skrillex-would-you-ever/ |archive-date=2 June 2018 |accessdate=2 June 2018}} | [[Skrillex]]
(featuring [[Poo Bear]]) |- !scope="row"| "Disinstegrate Slowly"{{Cite web |url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/10/1788-l-brings-renegade-funk-official-flip-glitch-mobs-disintegrate-slowly/ |title=1788-L brings renegade funk with official flip of The Glitch Mob’s 'Disintegrate Slowly' |last=Norris |first=Asher |date=29 October 2018 |website=[[Dancing Astronaut]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181029162658/https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/10/1788-l-brings-renegade-funk-official-flip-glitch-mobs-disintegrate-slowly/ |archive-date=30 October 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}} | [[The Glitch Mob]] |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Electronic musicians]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = 2562 | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = Dave Huismans | alias = A Made Up Sound
Dogdaze | birth_date =1979 | death_date = | origin = [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] | instrument = | genre = [[Future garage]], [[broken beat]], [[dubstep]], [[techno]], [[outsider house]] | occupation = [[Record producer]], [[Disc jockey|DJ]] | years_active = | label = [[Tectonic (record label)|Tectonic]] }} '''Dave Huismans''' (born 1979), better known by his [[stage name]] '''2562,''' is a musician from [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]].{{cite web|url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?926|title=2562: Dubstep in the area|date=21 July 2008|work=Resident Advisor|accessdate=17 April 2010}} Having previously released records of various musical styles under the monikers '''A Made Up Sound''' and '''Dogdaze''',{{cite web|author=zzzzamuel zzzztrang |url=http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/3432763 |title=Reviews - Album - 2562 |publisher=Drowned in Sound |date=2008-06-10 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} Huismans created 2562, under which his output is generally described as [[dubstep]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boomkat.com/item.cfm?id=95455 |title=2562, Aerial |publisher=Boomkat |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42836-2562-aerial |title=2562 - Aerial |publisher=The Skinny |date=2008-05-23 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/4332 |title=Dusted Reviews: 2562 - Aerial |publisher=Dustedmagazine.com |date=2008-06-02 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} He is known for producing dubstep that takes influence from techno as well.De opkomst van dubstep in de media ''[https://thesis.eur.nl/pub/10274/ Dr P.Berkers]'' The debut 2562 album, ''Aerial'' (Tectonic Records, 2008), was released to favourable reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |title=Sounds of the Universe — 2562 — Aerial |publisher=Soundsoftheuniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524061734/http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |archivedate=2011-05-24 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=517&Itemid=26 |title=2562's 'Aerial' view |publisher=FactMagazine |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}The Next Dubstep''[https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/aug/25/sceneandheard The Guardian]'' ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''In Dog We Trust'' (2006), Dogdaze Productions – as Dogdaze * ''Aerial'' (2008), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Shortcuts'' (produced 2004, released 2008), - as Made Up Sound * ''Unbalance'' (2009), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Fever'' (2011), When In Doubt – as 2562 * ''Air Jordan'' (2012), When In Doubt - as 2562 * ''The new today'' (2014), When In Doubt - as 2562 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://myspace.com/2562dub 2562] on [[Myspace]] * {{Discogs artist | artist = 2562 | name = 2562 }} * [http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=581&Itemid=27 ''FactMagazine'' interview (05/2008)] * [http://www.beatportal.com/feed/item/2562-video-interview/ Beatportal interview (10/2008)] * [https://archive.is/20130205211702/http://www.vectormeldrew.com/2009/08/2562-unbalance-album-artwork/ 2562 Unbalance Artwork Designer (10/2008)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2562}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Dubstep musicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from The Hague]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 360 | image = 360 at his Falling and Flying CD signing.jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = 360 at his ''Falling & Flying'' CD Signing, [[Cheltenham, Victoria|Cheltenham]], February 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Matthew James Colwell | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|7|12|df=y}} | birth_place = | origin = [[Melbourne]], Victoria, Australia | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = Rapper, singer-songwriter | instrument = | years_active = 2006–present | label = Inertia, [[EMI Music Australia]], Soulmate, Forthwrite | associated_acts = Forthwrite, [[Diafrix]], [[Josh Pyke]], [[Gossling]], [[N'fa]], [[Pez (musician)|Pez]] | website = {{URL|360music.com.au}} }} '''Matthew James Colwell''' (born 12 July 1986), better known by his [[stage name]] '''360''', is an Australian [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist. He has released four studio albums: ''What You See Is What You Get'' (2008); ''[[Falling & Flying]]'' (2011), which peaked at No. 4 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] and was certified platinum; ''Utopia'' (2014), and "Vintage modern" (2017). 360's second album provided four charting singles, including "[[Boys like You (360 song)|Boys like You]]", which peaked at No. 3 on the ARIA Singles Chart and was certified 4× platinum. At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], he received six nominations and won the '[[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release|Breakthrough Artist – Release]]' award for ''Falling & Flying'', while Styalz Fuego won the ARIA 'Producer of the Year' Artisan award for the same album.{{cite web|author1=Nicholas Jones|title=360, Gotye Lead Nominations For 2012 ARIA Awards|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/208671/360-gotye-lead-nominations-2012-aria-awards.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=3 October 2012}} ==Early life== 360 was born on 12 July 1986.{{cite web | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) | title = 'Died This Way' at APRA search engine | url = http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/worksearch.axd?q=Died%20This%20Way | accessdate = 1 December 2012 }} He attended [[Luther College (Victoria)|Luther College]] in Melbourne's eastern suburbs and graduated from [[Box Hill Senior Secondary College]].{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Music== ===2003-2006: Early Career=== 360 made his first official appearance in 2003 on fellow Australian rapper Infallible's EP ''A Burning Ambition'', on the track "Situation Critical" along with MCs [[Hunter (rapper)|Hunter]] and Versa. The following year, he released his debut solo EP, titled ''Rarities'', in which three of its four tracks featured his rap partner and best friend [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]. In 2005, Pez and 360 released a song called "Nutcase", which 360 described as a "fuck around track [that was] written and recorded in one day. Trying to make you laugh, or cringe". 360 was featured on Sydney producers Weapon X and Ken Hell's 2006 mixtape ''Scar-Non III: Kick To The Head'' with the song "In Da Chub", a remix of [[50 Cent]]'s 2003 hit [[In da Club|"In Da Club"]]. ===2007–2012: ''What You See Is What You Get'', ''Falling & Flying''=== In February 2007, he signed to Soulmate Records.{{cite web|url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/artists/ |title=Soulmate Records Artist Profiles |publisher=Soulmate Records |accessdate=13 December 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |title=360 signs with Soulmate Records |publisher=Ground Up Hip-Hop |date=4 February 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921181046/http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |archivedate=21 September 2007 }} He released his debut album, ''What You See Is What You Get'', on 22 March 2008. An ''InTheMix'' reviewer found 360 "not only showcases his hilariously funny comedic side but demonstrates his ability to approach more serious and personal issues, producing a well rounded album".{{cite news | url = http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | title = 360 ''What You See Is What You Get'' Album Launch | work = InTheMix | publisher = [[Sound Alliance]] | date = 12 April 2008 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927015013/http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | archive-date = 27 September 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} In a video interview for ''Peak Street Magazine'', 360 described his musical style as a combination of "some [[pop music|pop]] influences, [[electro (music)|electro]], [[dubstep]], and unintelligent rhymes".{{cite web | last=James | first=Sam | title=360 Interview with ''Peak Street'' | url=http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131061052/http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | dead-url=yes | archive-date=31 January 2013 | work=Peak Street Magazine | accessdate=2 December 2012 | first2=Danny | last2=Haneman | first3=Aisha | last3=Glen | date=19 June 2011 }} On 14 January 2008, 360 released a music video of "Mamma Mia", which depicts his desire for [[Bec Hewitt]] and mocked her husband, [[Lleyton Hewitt]], which was the Video of the Week on MySpace.com's Australian hip hop page.{{Cite news | url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/song-slams-trophy-wife-bec/story-e6frf96x-1111115315578 | title=Rapper 360 makes Bec Hewitt lustful object of lyrics | publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times]] ([[News Corporation]]) |work=[[Herald Sun]] | date=14 January 2008 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }}{{Cite news | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/rapper-360-targets-bec-and-lleyton-hewitt-in-myspace-video/story-e6frewyr-1111115314399 | title=Rapper 360 targets Bec and Lleyton Hewitt in MySpace video | date=14 January 2008 | publisher=[[News Limited]] ([[News Corporation]]) | work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} 360 described it as a comedic effort, "I wanted to take the piss out of them ... It's not meant to be taken too seriously she's not really my type". Management for the couple dismissed the rapper's effort as "a publicity stunt". By March 2010, he remained signed with Soulmate Records, which had signed a distribution deal with [[EMI Records]].{{cite web | url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/2010/03/15/soulmate-records-x-emi-partnership// |title=Soulmate Records partners with EMI |publisher=Soulmate Records | date=15 March 2010 | accessdate=13 December 2010 }} In December that year, his single, "Just Got Started" (featuring [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]), was released.{{cite web | url = https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/just-got-started-feat.-pez/id406702982 | title = 'Just Got Started' (feat. Pez) – Single by 360 | work = [[iTunes]] | publisher = [[Apple Inc.]] | date = 17 December 2010 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} By March the following year, it peaked at No. 59 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]], and at No. 21 on the ARIA Urban Singles Chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/industry/2011/04/04/chart-wrap-up-britney-beats-radiohead-to-1/ |title=Chart Wrap Up Britney Beats Radiohead To 1 |publisher=The Music Network |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20110530-1606/Issue1099.pdf|title=The ARIA Report – 21 March 2011 |publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association |accessdate=30 March 2012}} 360's second album, ''[[Falling & Flying]]'', was released on 30 September 2011{{Cite news|url=http://www.cairns.com.au/article/2011/01/13/144105_entertainment.html|title=360 is flying and falling...|publisher=[[The Cairns Post]]|date=13 January 2011|last=Kuch|first=Jesse|accessdate=27 April 2011}} which reached No. 4 on the ARIA Albums Chart,{{cite web | url = http://www.australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and remained in the number-one position of the Australian [[iTunes]] charts for three weeks. By October 2012, ''Falling & Flying'' was certified platinum by ARIA for shipments of 70,000 units,{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and was certified double platinum by July 2014.{{cite web|author1=James Jennings|title=360: Alive and Kicking|url=http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|website=Rolling Stone Australia|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=2 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021113403/http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|archive-date=21 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In November 2011, the fourth single from the album, "Boys like You" (featuring Gossling), was released, which peaked at No. 3 on the Australian singles chart in February 2012. The track also reached the top 40 of the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]].{{cite web | url = http://charts.org.nz/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = New Zealand Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} The single was certified 4× platinum by ARIA for shipments of 280,000 units.{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=single|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} His following singles, "Child" (April 2012) and "Run Alone" (August), both reached the ARIA 'Singles Top 30' chart. "Child" was certified platinum and "Run Alone" received a gold certification. The national Australian "Flying Tour" occurred in support of the album, and 360 was supported by new Melbourne artist Bam Bam.{{cite web|title=Bam Bam|url=https://www.triplejunearthed.com/artist/bam-bam|website=triple j Unearthed|publisher=ABC|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=3 June 2013}} ===2012–present: ''Utopia'' & ''Vintage Modern''=== In June 2012, 360 revealed to national youth broadcaster [[Triple J]] that he was already working on his third album, describing the upcoming release as "quite a dark album". He described it further, "No one sees behind the scenes and there's been a lot of bad (expletive) going on in my family life and personal life". 360 hinted at a diverse production line-up for the album, saying he has "been getting a gang of beats from all different people".{{cite web|title=360 readies "dark" new album|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3518538.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=5 June 2012}} A video, published on 21 November 2013, served as the official press release for the launch of Forthwrite Records, a music label created by 360 and Pez. 360 then confirmed the announcement on his Facebook page the following day, stating that the label will release ''Don't Look Down'', by Pez, ''[[Utopia (360 album)|Utopia]]'', by 360, and the debut, yet untitled Forthwrite album.{{cite web|author1=360|title=22 November 2013|url=https://en-gb.facebook.com/3ree6ixty/posts/10153511253795367|website=360 on Facebook|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=22 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=FORTHWRITE RECORDS Media Release 21 Nov 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRkQ8OvXr3A|website=FORTHWRITE on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 November 2013}} During his performance at the 2013 Sprung Hip Hop Festival, held in [[Brisbane]], Australia, 360 garnered media attention for the manner in which he introduced a new song titled "On A Planet No One Knows". According to 360, the song, which also features a vocal sample from [[Joss Whedon]] regarding gender equality, is "about racism in Australia."{{cite web|title=WATCH: 360 – 'On A Planet No One Knows’|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/tv/watch-360-on-a-planet-no-one-knows/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014}} 360 exclaimed:
There's a lot of racist cunts in this country [Australia]. I don't know if people are proud to admit it, or what—but there is. No matter what colour or background we are, there are fuckheads in every single race. Generalising everyone is fucking ignorant and uneducated and stupid. If you're offended by this then you're probably fuckin' racist and you should fuck off.{{cite web|author1=Mike Hohnen|title=360 Calls Out Racist Australia During New Song At Sprung Hip Hop Festival|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/360-calls-out-racist-australia-during-new-song-at-sprung-hip-hop-festival/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=7 October 2013}}
In February 2014, 360 supported the Australian tour of American rapper [[Eminem]], alongside [[Kendrick Lamar]]. 360 described the tour as a career highlight and explained to the media in January 2014 that it would be his first tour sober—he had previously struggled with drug addiction.{{cite news|author1=Lisa Visentin|title=360 announces tour of Australia|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/360-announces-tour-of-australia-20140527-zrpdp.html|accessdate=20 October 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 May 2014}} Prior to the release of the artist's third album, ''Utopia'', on 13 June 2014, three singles were released: "Impossible", "On A Planet No One Knows" and "Sixavelli". "Impossible" is a collaboration with [[Daniel Johns]], of Australian band [[Silverchair]], and Johns also appears in the music video, in which he is a passenger in a car driven by 360.{{cite web|title=360 - Impossible (Ft Daniel Johns) Official Video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xU78NDpJt08|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=16 January 2014}} A music video was also released for the second single and was published on the artist's YouTube channel during the week before [[Australia Day]].{{cite web|title=360 - ON A PLANET NO ONE KNOWS|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qUWJZSbGF7s|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 January 2014}} The music video for "Sixavelli" was directed by Claudia Sangiorgi Dalimore and was published in March 2014.{{cite web|title=360 - Sixavelli (Feat. Lunar C)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IN3DtQ_aCFI&list=UUHe7RBRU1OHq0h_Yb4VTUeg|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=25 March 2014}} Alongside fellow Australian hip hop act [[Hilltop Hoods]], 360 performed at the 2014 [[Splendour In The Grass]] festival, held in [[Byron Bay]], Australia.{{cite web|title=Splendour In The Grass 2014 lineup|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3990250.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=23 April 2014}} The Australian "Utopia Tour" occurred during September 2014 and 360 was supported by US rapper Hopsin, UK artist Lunar C, Pez and Miracle.{{cite web|author1=Jed Ahern|title=360 ANNOUNCES UTOPIA TOUR SUPPORT ACTS|url=http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|website=V Music|publisher=Foxtel Management Pty Ltd|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923110500/http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|archive-date=23 September 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Collaborations== During the early years of his music career, 360 collaborated with Pez as part of a duo called "Forthwrite",{{cite web|title=ForthWrite - 'Guilty Conscience'|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDxVFtjCxyI|website=PEZ on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2011}} including a track called "The Club Song" on the 2010 album ''[[Good Gracious]]'', by producer [[M-Phazes]].{{cite web|title=Good Gracious M-Phazes|url=https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/good-gracious/id359623656|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=26 February 2010}} 360 also featured on Pez's 2008 single, "The Festival Song", which peaked at No. 14 on the ARIA Australian Singles Chart.{{cite web | url = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20090120-0000/issue985.pdf | title = ARIA Report – 12th Jan 2009 | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association | issue = 985 | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | date = 12 January 2009 | accessdate = 2 December 2012}} In 2010, 360 started an online musical project in the Australian hip hop scene, called "Rapper Tag", on YouTube.{{cite web |url=http://www.rappertag.com:80/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712043422/http://www.rappertag.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 July 2012 |title=Rapper Tag |publisher=360 |accessdate=4 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Rapper Tag involves one person recording a portion of rap over a looped beat, and then nominating ("tagging") another person to add further rapping over the same loop. The process continued in accordance with the nomination of the next rapper.{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3076379.htm |title=Triple J: 360 Rapper Tag Phenomenon |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.optimising.com.au/blog/interview-on-social-media-with-melbourne-rapper-360/|date=9 March 2011|author=Daniel |title=Interview on Social Media with Melbourne Rapper 360 |accessdate=9 March 2011}} Australian hip hop duo [[Diafrix]] collaborated with 360 for the song "I'm A Dreamer", which appears on the 2012 album ''Pocket Full Of Dreams''.{{cite web|title=Diafrix feat. 360 - I'm A Dreamer (Official Video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JXTRCDRkz34|website=diafrix lion on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2012}} 360 appeared on the self-titled debut album by Canberra producer, Ghosts in the Room, released on 14 September 2012 through Mudd Music. The album also features rappers Iron Solomon, Okwerdz and Kool G Rap.{{cite web|title=Ghosts in the Room Ghosts in the Room|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/ghosts-in-the-room/id537506609|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=14 September 2012}} ==Media appearances== 360 was a panel member for the 20 October 2014 edition of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) program ''[[Q&A (Australian talk show)|Q&A]]''. He appeared alongside [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]], a particle physicist, [[Richard Gill (conductor)|Richard Gill]], renowned conductor, and [[Nalini Joshi]], a notable Australian mathematician, to discuss the topic of "passion".{{cite web|author1=gregmoskovitch|title=Get The Popcorn, 360 Is A Panelist On Next Monday's Q&A|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/421594/360-will-appear-next-mondays-qa.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=15 October 2014}} 360 garnered media attention for his comments on the television program regarding racism in relation to Australia, Australian hip hop and the Australian flag. When questioned by the presenter, 360 replied:
On Australia Day, you see dudes walking around with their tops off, and they're getting on the drink and all that. And they've got an Australian flag wrapped around their neck. I've seen it so many times; like, I've been in a taxi where we've pulled up because these dickheads have been walking across the road—they just start yelling at the taxi driver, like: "Get out of the country! This is not your country!" ... And they're wearing Australian flags. I've seen it so much, like, growing up ... still today, you know what I mean?{{cite web|title=Australian flag represents racism: 360|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dndT4vq5CpE|website=ABC News (Australia) on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=21 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=20 October 2014}}
This response caused controversy,{{cite news|title=#BBCTrending: Has Australia's flag been co-opted by racists?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-29712614|accessdate=27 October 2014|work=BBC News|date=21 October 2014}} including the transference of the media spotlight onto Pez, who made comments on social media following 360's appearance. In addition to a message of support for his friend and musical collaborator, Pez also wrote that he also "got a bit offended"; however, he subsequently removed the sentence "To be honest, even I got a bit offended." from his original Facebook post. As of 24 October 2014, 360 had not retracted his ''Q&A'' comments and explained after the airing of the episode: "If you are not racist then you have nothing to be offended about."{{cite web|author1=Nastassia Baroni|title=Pez Admits To Being "Offended" By 360's 'Q&A' Comments|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/pez-admits-to-being-offended-by-360s-qa-comments/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=24 October 2014}} ==Personal life== {{outdated section|date=September 2016}} At the age of 18 years, 360 contracted a disease of his right eye, a [[cornea transplant]], which "left him with fuzzy vision" in that eye. A July 2014 feature article in ''Rolling Stone Australia'' stated that he is "legally blind in his right eye", while his left eye is "slowly deteriorating due to the degenerative eye disease Keratoconus". On 18 July 2010, 360 was involved in a [[go-kart]]ing accident while celebrating his birthday with Sydney-based hip hop artists [[Bliss n Eso]]. He suffered a torn [[artery]], lacerated [[pancreas]] and a damaged [[scrotum]].{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Cameron|title=Accident brings 360 perspective|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/accident-brings-360-perspective/story-e6frfn09-1226152049520|work=news.com.au| publisher = News Limited (News Corporation) | date = 29 September 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2012}} According to the rapper, "It [scrotum] wasn't ruptured, but it was ripped open ... The first thing I checked once I woke up was I didn't need to use a colostomy bag. My sex life is intact. There's no sex appeal if you use a colostomy bag". On 13 February 2012, 360 and Crystal Bale became engaged;{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Is Engaged To Crystal Bale!|url=http://www.take40.com/news/29098/rapper-360-is-engaged-to-crystal-bale!|work=take40.com|accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 Is Engaged!|url=http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|work=novafm.com.au|accessdate=18 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504133510/http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|archive-date=4 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the pair then separated on 24 December 2012.{{cite web|title=@crystallouu|url=https://twitter.com/crystallouu/status/283034663667257345|accessdate=31 December 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 degrees of separation for rapper 360 and fiancee Crystal Bale |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/degrees-of-separation-for-rapper-360-and-fiancee-crystal-bale/story-e6frewz0-1226543747857|accessdate=31 December 2012}} As of October 2014, 360 is listed as a supporter of the 'Oscar's Law' campaign, which seeks to raise public awareness about the detrimental effects of factory farming of companion animals.{{cite web|title=Home|url=http://www.oscarslaw.org/|work=Oscar's law|publisher=Oscar's Law|accessdate=13 October 2012|author=Debra Tranter|year=2010}} He also appeared in [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'s 'Ink not Mink' anti-fur campaign."[http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true Ink Not Mink! Rapper 360 Flashes His Tatts for PETA's Anti-Fur Campaign,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606033913/http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true |date=6 June 2014 }} ninemsn.com.au, 2 June 2014. 360 and Bale promoted awareness of suicide and depression issues. In mid-February 2012, he posted a video clip with the following statement: "I don't usually drop serious videos, but this is something I'm passionate about spreading awareness about. Even if you hate me, this has nothing to do with music—please share this around so as many people as possible can see it".{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Speaks Out About Suicide |url=http://www.take40.com/artists/5752/360/news/29226/watch:-rapper-360-speaks-out-about-suicide |work=take40.com |accessdate=1 December 2012 }} In September 2012, Bale posted her video, 'A Message from Crystal', which Beats Factory{{'}}s Robyn Morrison described as footage of Bale "talking about how she has been affected by suicide—multiple times ... [it] is sometimes hard to watch, but essential viewing".{{cite news | url = http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | title = 360's Fiancée Opens Up About Suicide | last = Morrison | first = Robyn | work = Beats Factory | date = 16 September 2012 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130114235912/http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | archive-date = 14 January 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} On 8 January 2016, 360 posted a song named ''I'm Sorry'' onto his [[Facebook]] page. It talked about his [[codeine]] addiction. His addiction resulted in him cancelling tours without notice. In the song 360 mentions how he didn't tell anyone because he felt like a burden. Because he was addicted to [[Nurofen Plus]], the pills could be bought without a prescription.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/melbourne-rapper-360-explains-how-prescription-drugs-almost-killed-him/news-story/1c867df0f625977f7dffcc8d63d8a08d|title=Melbourne rapper 360 explains how prescription drugs almost killed him|date=11 January 2016|access-date=16 January 2016|website=[[news.com.au]]|first1=Rohan|last1=Smith}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/music-videos/rappers-brutally-honest-painkiller-addiction-confession/news-story/b2e5a9077fe976f15716bba1630e10ee|title=Rapper’s brutally honest painkiller addiction confession|website=[[news.com.au]]|first=Emma|last=Reynolds}} In September 2016, 360 announced that he was diagnosed with [[unipolar depression]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/rapper-360s-candid-facebook-post-about-his-breakdown/news-story/0aeeb73b6e1f862c364e5e93b94d459a|title=Rapper 360 opens up about depression with heartbreaking post|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3797575/Rapper-360-reveals-struggle-unipolar-depression-heart-wrenching-essay.html|title=Rapper 360 reveals his struggle with unipolar depression.|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}} ==Accolades and awards== ===2011=== "Boys like You" was voted into the No. 8 position in the [[Triple J Hottest 100, 2011|Triple J Hottest 100 countdown of 2011]].{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/hottest100/11/fulllist.htm | title = Hottest 100 – 2011 Countdown, Full List | publisher = [[Triple J]], [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} Also that year, 360 was awarded the [[Channel V|Channel [V]]] 'Oz Artist of the Year', ahead of [[Guy Sebastian]] and [[Short Stack]],[http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ Oz Artist of the Year 2011 Entrants] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPGPChYD?url=http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ |date=14 October 2012 }}. vmusic.com.au and received the 'Jägermeister Most Hunted Award' at the [[Jägermeister]] Independent Music Awards [[Australian Independent Record Labels Association|(Australian Independent Record (AIR) Awards)]], which is voted by fans.[http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html The Winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403224000/http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html |date=3 April 2012 }}, Australian Independent Record Labels Association Ltd (AIR), 2012 ===2012=== At the 2012 AIR Awards, 360 won the 'Best Independent Hip Hop Album' award for ''Falling & Flying''.{{cite web|title=WINNERS ANNOUNCED – 2012 JAGERMEISTER INDEPENDENT MUSIC AWARDS|url=http://www.air.org.au/news/winners-announced-2012-jagermeister-independent-music-awards/|work=Australian Independent Record Labels Association|publisher=AIR|accessdate=18 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}} ===ARIA Awards=== At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], 360 was nominated in six categories and won the 'ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release' for ''Falling & Flying'', while Feugo won the 'Producer of the Year' in the Artisan section.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/year/2012 |title=2012 ARIA Awards Winners By Year |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) |accessdate=30 November 2012 }} {{Awards Urban Album|Best Urban Album]] || {{nom}} |- | [[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release|Breakthrough Artist – Release]] || {{won}} |- | ''Falling & Flying'' – 360 || [[ARIA Award for Best Male Artist|Best Male Artist]] || {{nom}} |- | ''Falling & Flying'' – Styalz Fuego || Producer of the Year || {{won}} |- | ''Falling & Flying'' – Scott Horscroft, Phillip Threlfall || [[ARIA Award for Engineer of the Year|Engineer of the Year]] || {{nom}} |- | ''Falling & Flying'' – Debaser || [[ARIA Award for Best Cover Art|Best Cover Art]] || {{nom}} |- | "[[Boys like You (360 song)|Boys like {{For|Andre Levins|A+ (rapper)}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = | name = A-Plus | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Adam Carter | alias = A-Plus | birth_date = May 10 1974 (age 44) | birth_place = [[Denver, Colorado]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | origin = Oakland, California, U.S. | instrument = [[Microphone]], [[Sampler (musical instrument)|sampler]] | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = | years_active = 1991–present | label = [[Hieroglyphics Imperium Recordings]]
[[Jive Records]] | associated_acts = [[Souls of Mischief]]
[[Hieroglyphics (band)|Hieroglyphics]] | website = http://www.hieroglyphics.com | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Adam Carter''', known by the [[stage name]], '''A-Plus''', is an [[United States|American]] [[rapping|rapper]] and [[Record producer|producer]]. He is one of the founding four members of the [[Oakland, California]]-based [[Alternative hip hop|underground hip hop]] group [[Souls of Mischief]], and, with Souls of Mischief, a part of the eight-person, alternative hip hop [[musical collective|collective]], the [[Hieroglyphics (band)|Hieroglyphics]]. == Biography == Born in [[Denver, Colorado]] as the son of [[Jamaica]]n [[immigration|immigrants]], A-Plus moved to [[Oakland, California]] with his family when he was 5 years old.{{cite web |url = http://www.soundslam.com/articles/interviews/interviews.php?interviews=in051214aplus|accessdate = 2007-02-03|author = Fruchter, Alexander|title = Public Service Announcement: A-Plus|publisher = ''SoundSlam.com''|year = 2003|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090323144248/http://soundslam.com/articles/interviews/interviews.php?interviews=in051214aplus|archivedate = 23 March 2009|deadurl = yes}} In [[kindergarten]], A-Plus met future [[Hieroglyphics (band)|Hieroglyphics]] member, [[Casual (rapper)|Casual]], and in [[elementary school]], met fellow [[Souls of Mischief]] member [[Tajai]].{{cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/hiphopinterview/casualint.html |accessdate=2007-02-03 |author=Jones, Todd E. |title=Interview: Casual |publisher=''Hip-Hop Interviews'' |year=2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kkmuUQ9A?url=http://www.geocities.com/hiphopinterview/casualint.html |archivedate=2009-10-24 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Tajai eventually introduced A-Plus to future Souls of Mischief members [[Phesto]] and [[Opio]], and the group formed in [[high school]] before releasing their debut album, ''[[93 'til Infinity]]'' on [[Jive Records]] in 1993.{{cite web | url = http://ensim.hieroglyphics.com/artists/souls/phesto-interview.html | accessdate = 2007-02-03 | author = StinkE | title = Phesto Interview | publisher = ''StinkE Productions'' | date = 1996-07-18 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060719094917/http://ensim.hieroglyphics.com/artists/souls/phesto-interview.html | archive-date = 2006-07-19 | dead-url = yes | df = }} After A-Plus and the Souls of Mischief were dropped by Jive, the group was incorporated into the Hieroglyphics in 1995, at the urging of [[Del tha Funkee Homosapien]]. A-Plus has contributed to all four Souls of Mischief albums, as well as the two Hieroglyphic studio albums. He has also produced or performed on solo projects of various Hieroglyphics' members. In 2005, A-Plus released a [[remix]] album, ''Pleemix, Vol. 1'', through [[Hieroglyphics Imperium Recordings]]. On May 1, 2007, A-Plus released his debut [[solo album]], ''My Last Good Deed'' through [[Hieroglyphics Imperium Recordings]]. The debut single is "Patna Please." == Discography == === Solo albums === *2007: ''My Last Good Deed'' *2011: ''Pepper Spray (EP) '' *2014: ''Molly's Dirty Water'' == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.discogs.com/artist/A-Plus Discogs Profile - A-Plus] * [http://www.hieroglyphics.com Hieroglyphics - Official Site] *{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p909431|label=A-Plus}} {{Hieroglyphics (band)}} {{Souls of Mischief}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:A-Plus}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American male rappers]] [[Category:American rappers of Jamaican descent]] [[Category:Hieroglyphics (group) members]] [[Category:Musicians from Denver]] [[Category:Rappers from Oakland, California]] [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:West Coast hip hop musicians]] [[Category:20th-century American rappers]] [[Category:21st-century American rappers]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2015}} '''Animat''' (''third-person indicative present of the [[Latin]] verb '''animō'''''),<ref>[http://www.verbix.com/webverbix/go.php?D1=9&H1=109&T1=animo "Animo" at Verbix Latin Verb Conjugator]. Retrieved July 22, 2015.</ref> meaning to "animate, give or bring life".<ref>[http://latin-dictionary.net/search/latin/animo "Animo" at Latdict Latin Dictionary and Grammar Resources]. Retrieved July 22, 2015.</ref>
'''Animats''' are artificial [[animal]]s, a contraction of [[animal]]-materials. The term includes physical robots and virtual simulations. Animat research, a subset of [[Artificial Life]] studies, has become rather popular since [[Rodney Brooks]]' seminal paper "Intelligence without representation". The word was coined by S.W. Wilson in 1985, in "Knowledge growth in an artificial animal", published in the first ''Proceedings'' ''of an International Conference on Genetic Algorithms and Their Applications''.
An example using the Animat model as proposed by Wilson is discussed at some length in chapter 9 of [[Stan Franklin]]'s book, [[Artificial Minds]]. In this implementation, the animat is capable of independent learning about its environment through application and evolution of pattern-matching rules called "taxons".
In 2001 Thomas DeMarse performed studies on '[[neurally controlled animat]]'. Every two years, the Society of Adaptive Behaviour meets and produces a proceedings on this topic. They also have a journal, ''[[Adaptive Behavior]]''.
[[Alan H Goldstein]] has proposed that, because [[nanobiotechnology]] is in the process of creating real animal-materials, speculative use of this term should be discouraged and its application become purely phenomenological. Based on the Animat Test (contained in the reference "I, Nanobot.") any nonbiological material or entity that exhibits the minimum set of behaviors that define a life form is, de facto, an Animat. Goldstein's basic premise is that in the age of nanobiotechnology it is necessary to follow the chemistry and molecular engineering rather than watching for the emergence of some pre-conceived minimum level of 'intelligence' such as an artificial neural network capable of adaptive phenomena. Goldstein has cautioned that there is a serious disconnect between the fields of nanobiotechnology and A-life based on profound differences in scientific training, experimental systems, and the different sets of terminology (jargon) these two fields have produced. Nanobiotechnologists (really molecular engineers who work with both biological and nonbiological molecules) are generally not concerned with complex systems per se; even when they are building molecular interconnects between such systems, e.g. neuroelectronic splices. A-Life researchers mainly take a systems-level approach. The enormous transformative power of novel molecular engineering has the potential to create Animats, true nonbiological life forms, whose relatively simple behavior would not fit into most standard A-Life paradigms. As a result, Goldstein argues, the first Animats may come into being completely unrecognized by either scientific community.
==See also== *[[Cultured neuronal network]]s *[[Hybrot]] *[[Pacrat]]
==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Thomas DeMarse work. *Stanley P. Franklin. "Artificial Life", in Artificial Minds. The MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1995: 185-207. *Alan H. Goldstein. "I, Nanobot." Salon.com, March 9, 2006. *S. W. Wilson, Knowledge growth in an artificial animal. In Proceedings of an International Conference on Genetic Algorithms and Their Applications (pp. 16–23), Grefenstette, J.J., ed., Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Assoc. (1985). http://www.eskimo.com/~wilson/ps/KGAA.pdf *S. W. Wilson. The animat path to AI. In J.-A. Meyer and S. Wilson, editors, From Animals to Animats, pages 15–21. MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1991. http://www.eskimo.com/~wilson/ps/animat.pdf
==External links== *The [http://animatlab.lip6.fr/ AnimatLab] of Laboratoire d'Informatique de Paris 6 (Lip6), headed by [https://web.archive.org/web/20060713203759/http://animatlab.lip6.fr/MeyerAccueilEn Jean-Arcady Meyer ] * [http://www.isab.org.uk/ International Society for Adaptive Behavior] *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wACltn9QpCc *http://www.cs.ucla.edu/~dt/animat-vision *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1-0eZytv6Qk *https://neurolab.gatech.edu/labs/potter/animat
[[Category:Artificial life]]

{{about|the hypothetical self-replicating spacecraft concept|the side game from Space Quest III|Astro Chicken}}
'''Astrochicken''' is the name given to a [[thought experiment]] expounded by [[theoretical physicist]] [[Freeman Dyson]]. In his book ''Disturbing the Universe'' (1979), Dyson contemplated how humanity could build a small, [[Self-replication|self-replicating]] automaton that could explore space more efficiently than a manned craft could. He attributed the general idea to [[John von Neumann]], based on a lecture von Neumann gave in 1948 titled ''The General and Logical Theory of Automata''. Dyson expanded on von Neumann's [[Automata theory|automata theories]] and added a biological component to them.
Astrochicken, Dyson explained, would be a one-kilogram [[spacecraft]] unlike any before it. It would be a creation of the intersection of biology, [[artificial intelligence]] and modern microelectronics—a blend of organic and electronic components. Astrochicken would be launched by a conventional spacecraft into space, like an egg being laid into space. Astrochicken would then hatch and start growing a solar-energy collector. The solar collector would feed an [[ion drive]] engine that would power the craft. Once Astrochicken entered a planet's vicinity, it would collect material from the moons and rings of the planet, taking in nutrients. It could land and take off using an auxiliary chemical rocket similar to that used by [[bombardier beetle]]s. It would periodically transmit details of its journey when it could make radio contact with Earth.
The term "astrochicken" does not occur in Dyson's earliest essays regarding [[Self-replicating_spacecraft#Von_Neumann_probes|von Neumann-inspired automata]]. The concept was announced in a lecture Dyson was giving in [[Adelaide, Australia]] on the subject of space exploration with [[biotechnology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abob.libs.uga.edu/bobk/ccc/cc121802.html|title=Cambridge Conference Correspondence|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> An audience member called out "Oh, you mean this is an astro-chicken." and the whimsical name caught on, with Dyson beginning to use it himself in subsequent essays he wrote on his theoretical biotechnology spacecraft.
Today, Dyson's Astrochicken resonates with several theories of how space exploration might proceed in the future. Computer scientist [[Rodney Brooks]] has proposed sending a multitude of cheap, bug-like robots to explore Mars instead of solitary, expensive rovers. Cheaper and smaller means of studying space have also been the primary design philosophy of [[NASA]] for many years, perhaps best exemplified by the [[Mars Pathfinder]] mission. Physicist and noted author [[Michio Kaku]] wrote in his work ''Hyperspace'', "Small, lightweight, and intelligent, Astrochicken is a versatile space probe that has a clear advantage over the bulky, exorbitantly expensive space missions of the past, which have been a bottleneck to space exploration. ... It will not need huge quantities of rocket fuel; it will be bred and programmed to 'eat' ice and hydrocarbons found in the rings surrounding the outer planets".
As a noted author of essays on the possibilities of science in the future, Dyson's theories, such as the [[Dyson sphere]] and the [[Dyson tree]], have become popular in the scientific and [[science fiction]] communities. The more whimsically named "Astrochicken" has not achieved this same level of fame.
== See also ==
* [[Bioship]] * [[Grey goo]] * [[Interstellar travel]]-[[Intergalactic travel]] * [[Panspermia]] * [[Space colonization]] * [[Self-replicating machine]] * [[Von Neumann probe]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Artificial life]] [[Category:Robotic concepts]] [[Category:Hypothetical spacecraft]] [[Category:Freeman Dyson]] [[Category:Thought experiments in physics]] [[Category:Self-replicating machines]]

{{Use Harvard referencing|date=December 2017}} {{italic title}} [[File:Baopuzi.JPG|thumb|First Page of ''Baopuzi'' Inner Chapter 9]] [[File:Laojunfu.gif|thumb|''Laojun rushan fu'' 老君入山符 "Lord [[Laozi|Lao]]'s amulet for entering mountains" from ''Baopuzi'' Inner Chapter 17]] The '''''Baopuzi''''' ({{zh|s=抱朴子|t=抱朴子|p=Bàopǔzǐ|w=Pao-p'u-tzu|l=[Book of the] Master Who Embraces Simplicity}}), written by the [[Jin dynasty (265–420)|Jin dynasty]] scholar [[Ge Hong]] 葛洪 (283-343), is divided into esoteric ''Neipian'' 內篇 "Inner Chapters" and exoteric ''Waipian'' 外篇 "Outer Chapters". The [[Daoist]] Inner Chapters discuss topics such as techniques for [[Xian (Taoism)|''xian'']] 仙 "immortality; transcendence", [[Chinese alchemy]], elixirs, and demonology. The [[Confucianist]] Outer Chapters discuss [[Chinese literature]], [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalism]], politics, and society. ==Title== The [[eponymous]] title ''Baopuzi'' derives from Ge Hong's [[Art name|''hao'']] 號 "sobriquet; pseudonym" Baopuzi (lit. "embrace simplicity master"), which compounds ''bao'' [[Wikt:抱|抱]] "embrace; hug; carry; hold in both arms; cherish", ''[[Pu (Daoism)|pu]]'' or [[Wikt:朴|朴]] "uncarved wood, [a [[Taoism#Pu|Daoist metaphor]] for a] person's original nature; simple; plain", and ''zi'' [[Wikt:子|子]] "child; offspring; master [title of respect]". ''Baopu'' is a classical allusion to the ''[[Daodejing]]'' (19, tr. Mair 1990:181), "Evince the plainness of undyed silk, embrace the simplicity of the unhewn log; lessen selfishness, diminish desires; abolish learning and you will be without worries." Ge Hong's autobiography explains choosing his [[pen name]] Baopuzi.
It has been my plan to preserve regularity and not to follow the whims of the world. My speech is frank and sincere; I engage in no banter. If I do not come upon the right person, I can spend the day in silence. This is the reason my neighbors call me Simplex (''Pao-p'u''), which name I have used as a sobriquet in my writings. (tr. Ware 1966:10)
Compare these autobiography translations: (Davis and Ch'en 1941:301) "people all call me a ''pao-p'u'' scholar (i.e., one who keeps his basic nature, one who is unperturbed by the desires of the world)"; (Sailey 1978:251) "among the people of his district there were those who called him "The Scholar Who Embraces Simplicity"." Wu and Davis (1935:224) noted, "This name has been translated ''Old Sober-Sides'', but Dr. Wu considers that it has no satirical intent and would better be translated ''Solemn-Seeming Philosopher''." Fabrizio Pregadio (2006:2) translates "Master Who Embraces Spontaneous Nature". ==History== Compared with many other Daoist texts, the origins of the ''Baopuzi'' are well documented. Ge completed the book during the Jianwu 建武 era (317–318), when [[Emperor Yuan of Jin]] founded the Eastern Jin Dynasty, and revised it during the Xianhe 咸和 era (326-334). Ge Hong's autobiography (Outer Chapter 50) records writing the ''Baopuzi''.
In my twenties I planned to compose some little things in order not to waste my time, for it seemed best to create something that would constitute the sayings of one sole thinker. This is when I outlined my philosophical writing, but it was also the moment when I became involved in armed rebellion and found myself wandering and scattered even farther afield, some of my things getting lost. Although constantly on the move, I did not abandon my brush again for a dozen or so years, so that at the age of 37 or 38 [A.D. 317-18] I found my work completed. In all, I have composed ''Nei p'ien'' in 20 scrolls, ''Wai p'ien'' in 50; … [list of other writings, totaling 310 scrolls] My ''Nei p'ien'', telling of gods and genii, prescriptions and medicines, ghosts and marvels, transformations, maintenance of life, extension of years, exorcising evils, and banishing misfortune, belongs to the Taoist school. My ''Wai p'ien'', giving an account of success and failure in human affairs and of good and evil in public affairs, belongs to the Confucian school. (tr. Ware 1966:17, cf. Sailey 1978:264)
Compare the more literal translation of Davis and Ch'en (1941:301), "I left off writing for ten and odd years, for I was constantly on the road, until the era Chien-wu 建武 (317-318 A.D.) when I got it ready." Ge's autobiography mentions his military service fighting rebels against the Jin Dynasty, and successfully defending his hometown of Jurong 句容 (in modern [[Zhenjiang]], [[Jiangsu]]). In 330 (tr. Ware 1966:20), [[Emperor Cheng of Jin]] granted Ge the fief of "Marquis of [[Guanzhong]]" with income from 200 Jurong households. Scholars believe Ge revised the ''Baopuzi'' during this period, sometime around 330 (Komjathy 2004:22) or 332 (Wu and Davis 1935:224). The ''Baopuzi'' consists of 70 ''pian'' 篇 "chapters; books" divided between the 20 "Inner Chapters" and 50 "Outer Chapters" (cf. the ''[[Zhuangzi (book)|Zhuangzi]]'' textual division). [[Nathan Sivin]] (1969:389) described it as "not one book but two, considerably different in theme". The ''Neipian'' and ''Waipian'' "led entirely separate physical existences; they were not combined under a single title until a millennium after Ko's time". The (1444–1445) [[Ming Dynasty]] ''[[Daozang]]'' "Daoist canon" first printed the two ''Baopuzi'' parts together. This ''Zhengtong Daozang'' 正統道藏 "Daoist Canon of the [[Zhengtong Emperor|Zhengtong]] Era (1436-1450)" bibliographically categorized the ''Baopuzi'' under the ''Taiqing'' 太清 "Supreme Clarity" section for alchemical texts. ''Daozang'' editions encompass six ''juan'' (卷 "scrolls; fascicles; volumes"), three each for the Inner and Outer Chapters. Most received versions of ''Baopuzi'' descend from this Ming ''Daozang'' text. ==Content== The ''Baopuzi'' Inner and Outer Chapters discuss miscellaneous topics ranging from [[esotericism]] to [[social philosophy]]. The Inner Chapters discuss techniques of [[Xian (Taoism)|''xian'']] 仙 "immortality; transcendence", [[Chinese alchemy]], meditation, [[Daoist yoga]], [[Daoyin]], [[Taoist sexual practices|sexual techniques]], [[Chinese herbology]], demons, and [[Fulu|''fu'']] 符 "magic talismans". The Outer Chapters discuss [[Chinese philosophy]], [[Confucianism]], [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|Legalism]], government, politics, literature, scholarship, and include Ge's autobiography, which Waley (1930:10) called "the fullest document of this kind that early China produced". According to Ge Hong's autobiography, he divided the Inner and Outer Chapters on the distinction between [[Daoism]] and [[Confucianism]]. Ge philosophically described Daoism as the ''ben'' 本 "root; trunk; origin" and Confucianism as the ''mo'' 末 "tip; branch; end" (Inner Chapter 10, tr. Ware 1966:165). When asked, "Which has the priority, Confucianism or Taoism?" – Baopuzi replies, "Taoism is the very trunk of Confucianism, but Confucianism is only a branch of Taoism." While the ''Baopuzi'' Inner and Outer Chapters differ in content, they share a general format with an unnamed interlocutor posing questions and Ge Hong providing answers. The conventional syntax is ''Huowen yue'' 或問曰 "Someone asked, saying" and ''Baopuzi da yue'' 抱樸子答曰 "Baopuzi answered, saying". ===Inner Chapters=== The twenty ''Neipian'' "Inner Chapters" record arcane techniques for achieving ''xian'' "transcendence; immortality". These techniques span two types of Chinese alchemy that [[Tang Dynasty]] scholars later differentiated into ''[[neidan]]'' 內丹 "internal elixir; internal alchemy" and ''[[waidan]]'' 外丹 "external elixir; external alchemy". The word ''dan'' [[Wikt:丹|丹]] "[[cinnabar]]; red; pellet; [Chinese medicine] pill" means "[[Pill of Immortality|pill of immortality]], or [[elixir of life]]. Ge Hong details his researches into the arts of transcendence and immortality. "Internal alchemy" concerns creating an "immortal body" within the corporeal body through both physiological methods (dietary, respiratory, sexual, etc.) and mental practices (meditation, visualization, etc.). "External" or "laboratory alchemy" concerns compounding elixirs (esp. from minerals and metals), writing ''fu'' talismans or amulets, herbalism, and exorcism. Lai outlines the Inner Chapters subjects:
(1) proofs of the ''per se'' existence of immortals and transcendent states of immortality of the body; (2) stipulation of the accessibility to the perfect state of long life to everyone, irrespective of one's social status but dependent on whether one could study deeply and strenuously cultivate the necessary esoteric methods; (3) elaboration of diverse esoteric techniques leading one to become a ''hsien''-immortal; and (4) descriptions and criticism of the diverse contemporary Taoist discourses and sects. (1998:191-2)
Several chapters have specific themes. Chapters 4, 8, 11, and 16 describe ''waidan'' "external alchemy". Inner Chapter 18 details meditation practices. In Chapter 19, Ge Hong praises his master Zheng Yin 鄭隱 (ca. 215-ca. 302), catalogues Daoist books, and lists talismans (see Ware 1966:379-385). {| class="wikitable" |+ Table 1: The ''Neipian'' 內篇 "Inner Chapters" |- ! Number !! Pinyin!! Characters !! [[Joseph Needham]] (1954:437), who called Ge Hong "the greatest alchemist in Chinese history", quoted the following passage about medicines from different biological categories.
''Interlocutor'': Life and death are predetermined by fate and their duration is normally fixed. Life is not something any medicine can shorten or lengthen. A finger that has been cut off cannot be joined on again and expected to continue growing. Blood from a wound, though swallowed, is of no benefit. Therefore, it is most inappropriate to approve of taking such nonhuman substances as pine or thuya [cypress] to protract the brief span of life.
''Ko'': According to your argument, a thing is beneficial only if it belongs to the same category as that which is treated. … If we followed your suggestion and mistrusted things of a different type, we would be obliged to crush flesh and smelt bone to prepare a medicine for wounds, or to fry skin and roast hair to treat baldness. Water and soil are not of the same substance as the various plants; yet the latter rely upon them for growth. The grains are not of the same species as living men; yet living men need them in order to stay alive. Fat is not to be classed with fire, nor water with fish, yet when there is no more fat the fires dies, and when there is no more water, fish perish. (3, tr. Ware 1966:61-62)
Needham (1954:439) evaluated this passage, "Admittedly there is much in the ''Pao Phu Tzu'' which is wild, fanciful and superstitious, but here we have a discussion scientifically as sound as anything in Aristotle, and very much superior to anything which the contemporary occident could produce." In addition to quoting early alchemical texts, the Inner Chapters describe Ge Hong's laboratory experiments. Wu and Davis mention the ''Baopuzi'' formula for making [[mosaic gold]] "a golden crystalline powder used as a pigment" from ''chiyan'' 赤塩 "red crystal salt" (produced from [[amethyst]], [[calcite]] [[crystal]], and [[alum]]; Ware 1966:273) and ''huizhi'' 灰汁 "[[limewater]]".
The description of one process deserves special discussion, for it evidently concerns the preparation of stannic sulfide or "mosaic gold" and is perhaps the earliest known description of the preparation of this interesting substance. Mosaic gold exists in flakes or leaflets which have the color and the luster of gold, it does not tarnish, and is used at present for bronzing radiators, gilding picture frames and similar purposes. As Ko Hung describes the process, "tin sheets, each measuring six inches square by one and two-tenths inches thick, are covered with a one-tenth inch layer of a mud-like mixture of ''Ch'ih Yen'' (Red Salt) and ''Huei Chih'' (potash-water, limewater), ten pounds of tin to every four of ''Ch'ih Yen''." They are then heated in a sealed earthenware pot for thirty days with horse manure (probably with a smouldering fire of dried manure). "All the tin becomes ash like and interspersed with bean-like pieces which are the yellow gold." The large portion of the metallic tin is converted into some ash-like compound or possibly into the ash-like allotropic modification, gray tin. A small portion of the tin is converted into bean-sized aggregates of flaky stannic sulfide. The yield is poor, for the author says that "twenty ounces of gold are obtained from every twenty pounds of tin used." (1935:232)
The authors add, "It seems likely that Ko Hung was personally experienced in the chemistry of tin, for the Chinese say that he was the first to make [[tin foil]] and that he made magic or spirit money out of it." ===Outer Chapters=== The fifty ''Waipian'' "Outer Chapters" are more diffuse than the Inner ones. Ge Hong diversely wrote essays on Jin Dynasty issues in philosophy, morality, politics, and society. This ''Baopuzi'' portion details everyday problems among Han Dynasty northerners who fled into south China after the fall of [[Luoyang]]. Some of the Outer Chapters are thematically organized. Ge Hong wrote chapters 46, 47, and 48 to dispute three adversaries. Guo Tai 郭太 (128-169) founded of the ''[[Qingtan]]'' "pure conversation" school; Ni Heng 禰衡 (173-198) was an infamously arrogant official of [[Cao Cao]]; and [[Pao Ching-yen|Bao Jingyan]] 鮑敬言 (ca. 405-ca. 466) was an early anarchist philosopher. {| class="wikitable" |- |+ Table 2: The ''Waipian'' 外篇 "Outer Chapters" !
